passages.text: O - Outperform, M - Market-Perform, U - Underperform, NR - Not Rated, CS - Coverage Suspended Source: Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis.

We rate Suzuki Outperform with a price target of JPY 2,300. We rate Toyota Outperform with a price target of JPY 3,500. We rate Honda Market- Perform with a price target of JPY 1,400. We rate Nissan Underperform with a price target of JPY 250. We rate Mazda Underperform with a price target of JPY 700. We rate Subaru Underperform with a price target of JPY 2,250. We rate Toyota Industries Outperform with a price target of JPY 18,750. We rate Denso Market- Perform with a price target of JPY 2,100. We rate Aisin Market- Perform with a price target of Â¥2,000.

As we stated in our Japan Autos Returns Revolution report, we expect to see another wave of business and capital restructuring amid acceleration of the xEV transition, declining automaker volumes, and increasing regulatory/market focus on corporate governance. In 2025, the wave of privatization has already begun spreading to auto parts suppliers, starting with Toyota Fudosan's announcement to take Toyota Industries private, followed by Toyota Gosei's decision to privatize Ashimori Industry.

The number of take- privates in Japan has been on a rising trend and reached 76 as of 2025 YTD (vs. 34 in 2020), driven mainly by increasing costs of staying listed, the TSE's push to unwind parent- subsidiary listings, stricter listing requirements following market re- segmentation, and mounting market pressure to improve capital efficiency. As of now, the number of listed companies in Japan appears to be at an inflection point, set to decline for the first time in a decade. Compared with the US and UK, Japan maintains a disproportionately high number of listed firms relative to its GDP, suggesting ample room for privatizations. By market segment, the number of companies in the Prime and Standard markets, where legacy firms account for a large share, has declined by 98 since 2022, suggesting rising pressure on legacy industries in capital markets, including autos.

In Japan, the industrial sector accounts for a relatively large share of privatization transactions ( \(\sim 35\%\) during 2015- 2025), compared with the US ( \(\sim 17\%\) ) and Europe ( \(\sim 19\%\) ). Furthermore, the average takeover premium in Japan's industrial sector over the past decade stands at \(49.6\% - \sim 8\%\) higher than in other sectors- indicating an accretive opportunity for investors.

We analyzed privatized industrial companies in Japan since 2019, focusing on earnings, capex, net cash, shareholder returns, equity spread, size, valuation and shareholder. Based on this scoring, we ranked the 67 companies in our auto parts universe by similarity to past take- private cases. As a result, the top- ranked names included Toyota affiliates (Toyota Boshoku, Tokai Rika, Toyoda Gosei, Aisan Industry, Aichi Steel, and Trinity Industrial), Honda/Nissan affiliates (FCC/Nissan Shatai), as well as Seiren. These companies benefit from a stable customer base, which has supported steady profitability. At the same time, their businesses appear relatively mature and may lack significant new growth drivers. With increasing pressure to unwind parent- subsidiary listings, we believe the likelihood of privatizations among such companies could rise. For details of the analysis, please refer to Exhibit 13, Exhibit 14, Exhibit 15, and Exhibit 16.

Toyota Boshoku (3116 JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated seat supplier, with Toyota holding a \(40\%\) stake and roughly \(92\%\) of sales derived from the parent automaker. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(3.6\%\) and average OPM has been \(4.1\%\) , reflecting stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 12.7\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(3.2\%\) - about half the universe average of \(6\%\) - and only two equity offerings since 2000. Its core seat business remains highly dependent on Toyota's production volumes, and with limited new growth drivers, the company could be subject to group- level restructuring in the future, as seen in the Toyota Industries' buyout. Moreover, as we highlighted in Japan Autos Returns Revolution report, as the need for integrated cockpit development grows in the automotive sector, we see room for Toyota Boshoku, Toyota Gosei, and Tokai Rika to pursue further collaboration or restructuring/consolidation in the future. In August 2025, Toyota Gosei announced the full acquisition of seatbelt supplier Ashimori Industry, which could be seen as part of this broader trend. Furthermore, in our report titled "The House of Toyota", we analyzed 16 Toyota- affiliated suppliers that could be potential targets for restructuring under the new holding company of Toyota Fudosan. This analysis was conducted based on three criteria: dependence on Toyota, dependence on ICE, and equity spread, and Toyota Boshoku ranked \(7\%\) among these companies.

Tokai Rika (6995 JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(33\%\) stake, manufacturing a broad range of body components including switches, key locks, and seatbelts. About \(74\%\) of sales come from Toyota, reflecting relatively high dependence on the parent automaker. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(2.9\%\) and average OPM has been \(4.9\%\) , indicating stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 31.7\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(4.5\%\) and only one equity offering since 2000, making its financial profile similar to Toyota Boshoku. However, its core switch business faces structural headwinds as functions shift toward displays, raising concerns over demand decline. Similar to Toyota Boshoku, Tokai Rika could become part of group- level restructuring within Toyota, potentially including integration of interior/exterior suppliers under the theme of integrated cockpits.

FCC (7296 JP, not covered) is a Honda- affiliated supplier, with Honda holding a \(21\%\) stake, specializing in clutches. About \(37\%\) of sales are to Honda. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.9\%\) and average OPM \(6.4\%\) , reflecting stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 26.2\%\) ), and has conducted no equity offering since the early 2000s. With the long- term xEV transition inevitable, investors may focus on how Honda intends to manage its stake in FCC, particularly given its past track record of divesting listed affiliates such as Yachiyo Industry, which was sold to India's Motherson and subsequently privatized.

Toyoda Gosei (7282 JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(44\%\) stake, manufacturing exterior and interior parts, airbags, and weatherstrips. About \(68\%\) of sales come from Toyota, a slightly lower level of dependence compared with Toyota Boshoku and Tokai Rika. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.7\%\) and average OPM \(5.9\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company's average net debt- to- market cap ratio stands at \(7.4\%\) , suggesting relatively greater use of leverage versus Toyota Boshoku and Tokai Rika, though it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. In August 2025,

Toyoda Gosei announced the privatization of safety supplier Ashimori Industry, and going forward, investor attention may focus on Toyoda Gosei itself as well as potential restructuring moves among Toyota- affiliated interior and exterior suppliers.

Aisan Industry (7283 JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(36\%\) stake, manufacturing ICE- related products such as fuel pumps and throttle bodies. About \(55\%\) of sales are to Toyota. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(5.1\%\) and average OPM \(4.4\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 6.1\%\) ), and has conducted only two equity offers since 2000 (2004 and 2014). With roughly \(90\%\) of sales tied to ICE products, a fundamental transformation of the business will eventually be required amid the long- term xEV transition. Similar to Toyota Industries, Aisan Industry could become a target for restructuring under a Toyota Fudosan- led holding company.

Seiren is an independent textile processing company, with its automotive materials business (mainly seat fabrics and airbags), accounting for \(\sim 70\%\) of sales. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.5\%\) and average OPM \(9.3\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 6.0\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(4.7\%\) and no equity offerings since 2000. Seiren has a solid earnings base supported by transactions with multiple automakers, relatively high profitability within the auto sector, and operational excellence with an integrated production structure from raw yarn to finished products. While the company does not have a controlling shareholder, its strong financial profile may attract PE funds as a potential take- private candidate. In September 2024, media reports highlighted that the stake of a certain institutional investor had temporarily exceeded \(6\%\) .

Aichi Steel is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(44\%\) stake, specializing in specialty steel. About \(56\%\) of sales are to the Toyota group. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(3.8\%\) and average OPM \(3.3\%\) , reflecting stable performance, while the company has relatively higher leverage among the top- ranked names (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(30\%\) ). However, it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. With over \(70\%\) of sales tied to ICE products, a fundamental transformation of the business will eventually be required amid the long- term xEV transition, and similar to Toyota Industries, Aichi Steel could become a target for restructuring under a Toyota Fudosan- led holding company. In addition, Aichi Steel holds an important position in the Toyota group structure, having been separated from Toyota Industries (not from Toyota Motor), and it is noteworthy that in September 2024 an institutional investor disclosed a stake exceeding \(5\%\) . Furthermore, in our report titled "The House of Toyota", we analyzed 16 Toyota- affiliated suppliers that could be potential targets for restructuring under the new holding company of Toyota Fudosan. In this analysis, Aichi Steel ranked 3rd out of 16 companies.

Trinity Industrial is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(36\%\) stake, manufacturing and selling automotive painting plants and equipment. About \(36\%\) of sales are to the Toyota group. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(2.1\%\) and average OPM \(6.1\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a solid financial profile, with an average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 85\%\) and capex- to- sales of \(3.5\%\) , indicating limited need for external financing, and it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. Given its sound balance sheet, Trinity Industrial could become a candidate for restructuring within the Toyota group under Toyota Fudosan. At the same time, considering Toyota's 2025 decision to sell its stake in Chuo Pack Industry (a packaging materials maker) through a tender offer by Nikkon Holdings, the possibility of privatization by external parties cannot be ruled out.

Nissan Shatai (7222 JP, not covered) is a \(50\%\) - owned listed subsidiary of Nissan, responsible for part of Nissan's vehicle assembly. \(\sim 98\%\) of sales are to Nissan, highlighting its heavy dependence on the parent. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(- 4.1\%\) and average OPM has been just \(1.0\%\) , reflecting weak performance. At the same time, the company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 40.1\%\) ) and limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging only \(1.7\%\) , and it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. Multiple shareholders have already campaigned for unwinding the parent- subsidiary listing of Nissan and Nissan Shatai, and structurally it appears natural for Nissan to eventually privatize Nissan Shatai. However, we believe this is more likely to occur after FY3/26, once Nissan has made progress under its Re:Nissan restructuring plan.

Since the announcement of Toyota Fudosan's take- private of Toyota Industries on June \(3^{rd}\) , investor attention on privatizations in the auto parts sector has heightened. Amid intensifying capital market pressures, Japan has entered a privatization boom, with multiple auto parts suppliers exiting the capital market every year. In this note, we analyze the characteristics of take- private deals in Japan since 2019 and identify Japanese auto parts suppliers that could be potential candidates for privatization, based on similarities with past cases.

As we stated in our Japan Autos Returns Revolution report, we expect to see another wave of business and capital restructuring amid acceleration of the xEV transition, declining automaker volumes, and increasing regulatory/market focus on corporate governance. In 2025, the wave of privatization has already begun spreading to auto parts suppliers, starting with Toyota Fudosan's announcement to take Toyota Industries private, followed by Toyoda Gosei's decision to privatize Ashimori Industry. Looking at share price performance, Japan Auto Parts has outperformed both the Japan Autos sector and TOPIX 2025 YTD, and the performance gap vs. Autos appears to have widened due to restructuring/privatization expectations, following the announcement of Toyota Industries' buyout (Exhibit 1).

EXHIBIT 1: The Japan Auto Parts sector has outperformed both the Japan Autos sector and TOPIX 2025 YTD, and the gap vs. Autos looks to have widened following the announcement of Toyota Industries' buyout
Source: Bloomberg, Bernstein analysis

The number of take- privates in Japan has been on a rising trend and reached 76 as of 2025 YTD (vs. 34 in 2020), driven mainly by increasing costs of staying listed, the TSE's push to unwind parent- subsidiary listings, stricter listing requirements following market re- segmentation, and mounting market pressure to improve capital efficiency (Exhibit 2). As of 2025 YTD, the number of listed companies in Japan appears to be at an inflection point, set to decline for the first time in a decade (Exhibit 3). Compared with the US and UK, Japan maintains a disproportionately high number of listed firms relative to its GDP, suggesting ample room for further privatizations (Exhibit 4). By market segment, the number of companies in the Prime and Standard markets, where legacy firms account for a large share, has declined by 98 since 2022, suggesting rising pressure from capital markets on legacy industries, including autos (Exhibit 5). We believe key drivers include the TSE's push to unwind parent- subsidiary listings, stricter listing requirements following market re- segmentation, and mounting pressure to improve capital efficiency.

Looking at the share of take- privates within overall M&A activity, Japan stands out. While Europe and the US recorded roughly 4 times and 7 times as many M&A transactions as Japan on average during 2015- 2025 YTD (Exhibit 6), the number of take- privates is not materially different (Exhibit 2). As a result, take- privates account for a larger share of total M&A in Japan (3.4% in 2025 YTD), compared with 0.4% in the US and 1.3% in Europe.

In Japan, the industrial sector accounts for a relatively large share of privatization transactions ( \(\sim 35\%\) during 2015- 2025) with deal count already reaching 28 in 2025 YTD, compared with the US ( \(\sim 17\%\) ) and Europe ( \(\sim 19\%\) ) (Exhibit 7). Recently, major suppliers such as Toyota Industries, Ashimori Industry, Pacific Industrial, and SNT have decided to go private, and we expect this trend to continue. Furthermore, looking at the past decade in Japan, the average takeover premium in the industrial sector stands at \(49.6\% - 8\%\) higher than in other sectors- indicating an accretive opportunity for investors (Exhibit 8).

Looking at past privatization cases in the auto sector, one of the first was Colsonic Kansei (now Marelli), which was taken private by a PE fund in 2016. While the company is currently in the midst of a debt restructuring process, after privatization the influence of its former parent Nissan weakened, giving management more freedom to pursue strategies such as roll- up M&A. In 2017, JTEKT made JTEKT Column Systems, then a listed affiliate, a wholly owned subsidiary (Exhibit 9).

In 2021, Honda privatized three affiliated listed suppliers (Keihin, Showa, and Nissin Kogyo) to enhance their competitiveness, subsequently merging them to form Astemo (Honda's subsidiary) (Exhibit 10). In 2023, by contrast, Honda sold its stake in Yachiyo Industry (fuel tank) through a tender offer by India's Motherson, which subsequently privatized the target company. Similarly, Isuzu responded to a PE fund's tender offer by selling shares in JTT (engine cast parts), marking further privatizations among ICE suppliers (Exhibit 11). In 2025, a string of privatizations has taken place, including SNT (engine forged parts), Toyota Industries, Pacific Industrial (tire valves), and Ashimori Industry (airbags & seatbelts), underscoring rising momentum in privatizations in Japan Autos sector.

We analyzed privatized industrial companies in Japan since 2019- when M&A guidelines in Japan began to be clarified- focusing on earnings, capex, net cash, shareholder returns, equity spread, size, valuation and shareholder (Exhibit 13). We believe companies that tend to be subject to privatization share several common characteristics. Those with stable earnings can sustain operations without relying heavily on external capital, while companies with limited capex needs are also able to fund investments internally, reducing reliance on public markets. Cash- rich companies similarly have less need for continuous financing. From a shareholder perspective, companies with low shareholder return ratios or those unable to generate returns (ROE) above their cost of equity show limited focus on shareholders, weakening the rationale for remaining listed. Privatization is also more feasible for smaller companies, where the required funding size is lower, and for those trading at low valuations, which may be considered undervalued relative to fundamentals. Finally, companies with controlling shareholders may pursue privatization more readily, particularly against the backdrop of unwinding parent- subsidiary listings and a stronger emphasis on minority shareholder protection.

Based on these characteristics, we calculated the corresponding metrics from privatized industrial companies in Japan since 2019. After excluding certain outliers, we established scoring bands around the mean of these metrics, and then assigned scores to the 67 companies in our auto parts sector universe: if a company's metric fell within \(\pm 0.5\) s.d. (standard deviation) of the mean, it received 5 points; within \(\pm 1\) s.d. 4 points; within \(\pm 1.5\) s.d., 3 points; within \(\pm 2\) s.d., 2 points; and outside \(\pm 2\) s.d., 1 point (Exhibit 15, Exhibit 16). Based on this scoring, we ranked the 67 companies in our auto parts universe by similarity to past take- private cases.

As a result, the top- ranked names included Toyota affiliates (Toyota Boshoku, Tokai Rika, Toyoda Gosei, Aisan Industry, Aichi Steel, and Trinity Industrial), Honda/Nissan affiliates (FCC/Nissan Shatai), as well as Seiren. These companies benefit from the stable customer base, which has supported steady profitability. At the same time, their businesses appear relatively mature and may lack significant new growth drivers. With increasing pressure to unwind parent- subsidiary listings, we believe the likelihood of privatizations among such companies could rise (Exhibit 14).

Toyota Boshoku (3116. JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated seat supplier, with Toyota holding a \(40\%\) stake and roughly \(92\%\) of sales derived from the parent automaker. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(3.6\%\) and average OPM has been \(4.1\%\) , reflecting stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 12.7\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(3.2\%\) - about half the universe average of \(6\%\) - and only two equity offerings since 2000. Its core seat business remains highly dependent on Toyota's production volumes, and with limited new growth drivers, the company could be subject to group- level restructuring in the future, as seen in the Toyota Industries' buyout. Moreover, as we highlighted in Japan Autos Returns Revolution report, as the need for integrated cockpit development grows in the automotive sector, we see room for Toyota Boshoku, Toyota Gosei, and Tokai Rika to pursue further collaboration or restructuring/consolidation in the future. In August 2025, Toyota Gosei announced the full acquisition of seatbelt supplier Ashimori Industry, which could be seen as part of this broader trend. Furthermore, in our report titled "The House of Toyota", we analyzed 16 Toyota- affiliated suppliers that could be potential targets for restructuring under the new holding company of Toyota Fudosan. This analysis was conducted based on three criteria: dependence on Toyota, dependence on ICE, and equity spread, and Toyota Boshoku ranked 7th among these companies.

Tokai Rika (6995. JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(33\%\) stake, manufacturing a broad range of body components including switches, key locks, and seatbelts. About \(74\%\) of sales come from Toyota, reflecting relatively high dependence on the parent automaker. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(2.9\%\) and average OPM has been \(4.9\%\) indicating stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 31.7\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(4.5\%\) and only one equity offering since 2000, making its financial profile similar to Toyota Boshoku. However, its core switch business faces structural headwinds as functions shift toward displays, raising concerns over demand decline. Similar to Toyota Boshoku, Tokai Rika could become part of group- level restructuring within Toyota, potentially including integration of interior/exterior suppliers under the theme of integrated cockpits.

FCC (7296. JP, not covered) is a Honda- affiliated supplier, with Honda holding a \(21\%\) stake, specializing in clutches. About \(37\%\) of sales are to Honda. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.9\%\) and average OPM \(6.4\%\) , reflecting stable earnings. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 26.2\%\) ), and has conducted no equity offering since the early 2000s. With the long- term xEV transition inevitable, investors may focus on how Honda intends to manage its stake in FCC, particularly given its past track record of divesting listed affiliates such as Yachiyo Industry, which was sold to India's Motherson and subsequently privatized.

Toyoda Gosei (7282. JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(44\%\) stake, manufacturing exterior and interior parts, airbags, and weatherstrips. About \(68\%\) of sales come from Toyota, a slightly lower level of dependence compared with Toyota Boshoku and Tokai Rika. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.7\%\) and average OPM \(5.9\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company's average net debt- to- market cap ratio stands at \(7.4\%\) , suggesting relatively greater use of leverage versus Toyota Boshoku and Tokai Rika, though it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. In August 2025, Toyota Gosei announced the privatization of safety supplier Ashimori Industry, and going forward, investor attention may focus on Toyota Gosei itself as well as potential restructuring moves among Toyota- affiliated interior and exterior suppliers.

Aisan Industry (7283. JP, not covered) is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(36\%\) stake, manufacturing ICE- related products such as fuel pumps and throttle bodies. About \(55\%\) of sales are to Toyota. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(5.1\%\) and average OPM \(4.4\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 6.1\%\) ), and has conducted only two equity offerings since 2000 (2004 and 2014). With roughly \(90\%\) of sales tied to ICE products, a fundamental transformation of the business will eventually be required amid the long- term xEV transition. Similar to Toyota Industries, Aisan Industry could become a target for restructuring under a Toyota Fudosan- led holding company.

Ranked No.4 (tied): Seiren (Market cap JPY 196 bn, Sales JPY 160 bn, no controlling shareholder)Seiren is an independent textile processing company, with its automotive materials business (mainly seat fabrics and airbags), accounting for \(\sim 70\%\) of sales. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(4.5\%\) and average OPM \(9.3\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 6.0\%\) ) and has limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging \(4.7\%\) and no equity offerings since 2000. Seiren has a solid earnings base supported by transactions with multiple automakers, relatively high profitability within the auto sector, and operational excellence with an integrated production structure from raw yarn to finished products. While the company does not have a controlling shareholder, its strong financial profile may attract PE funds as a potential take- private candidate. In September 2024, media reports highlighted that the stake of a certain institutional investor had temporarily exceeded \(6\%\) .

Ranked No.7: Aichi Steel (Market cap JPY 225 bn, Sales JPY 299 bn, \(44\%\) owned by Toyota)Aichi Steel is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(44\%\) stake, specializing in specialty steel. About \(56\%\) of sales are to the Toyota group. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(3.8\%\) and average OPM \(3.3\%\) , reflecting stable performance, while the company has relatively higher leverage among the top- ranked names (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(30\%\) ). However, it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. With over \(70\%\) of sales tied to ICE products, a fundamental transformation of the business will eventually be required amid the long- term xEV transition, and similar to Toyota Industries, Aichi Steel could become a target for restructuring under a Toyota Fudosan- led holding company. In addition, Aichi Steel holds an important position in the Toyota group structure, having been separated from Toyota Industries (not from Toyota Motor), and it is noteworthy that in September 2024 an institutional investor disclosed a stake exceeding \(5\%\) . Furthermore, in our report titled "The House of Toyota", we analyzed 16 Toyota- affiliated suppliers that could be potential targets for restructuring under the new holding company of Toyota Fudosan. In this analysis, Aichi Steel ranked 3rd out of 16 companies.

Trinity Industrial is a Toyota- affiliated supplier, with Toyota holding a \(36\%\) stake, manufacturing and selling automotive painting plants and equipment. About \(36\%\) of sales are to the Toyota group. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(2.1\%\) and average OPM \(6.1\%\) , reflecting stable performance. The company maintains a solid financial profile, with an average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 85\%\) and capex- to- sales of \(3.5\%\) , indicating limited need for external financing, and it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. Given its sound balance sheet, Trinity Industrial could become a candidate for restructuring within the Toyota group under Toyota Fudosan. At the same time, considering Toyota's 2025 decision to sell its stake in Chuo Pack Industry (a packaging materials maker) through a tender offer by Nikkon Holdings, the possibility of privatization by external parties cannot be ruled out.

Nissan Shatai (7222. JP, not covered) is a \(50\%\) - owned listed subsidiary of Nissan, responsible for part of Nissan's vehicle assembly. \(- 98\%\) of sales are to Nissan, highlighting its heavy dependence on the parent. Over the past decade, sales CAGR has been \(- 4.1\%\) and average OPM has been just \(1.0\%\) , reflecting weak performance. At the same time, the company maintains a net cash position (average net debt- to- market cap ratio of \(- 40.1\%\) ) and limited funding needs, with capex- to- sales averaging only \(1.7\%\) , and it has not conducted any equity offerings since 2000. Multiple shareholders have already campaigned for unwinding the parent- subsidiary listing of Nissan and Nissan Shatai, and structurally it appears natural for Nissan to eventually privatize Nissan Shatai. However, we believe this is more likely to occur after FY3/26, once Nissan has made progress under its Re:Nissan restructuring plan.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 ppNeutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) ppUnderperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
